author: Sofia Martin
title: 7 Massive Thrift Stores In Nevada That Offers Outrageously Good Bargains
text:
Hunting for incredible secondhand deals in Nevada?
These 7 massive thrift stores deliver amazing bargains and unexpected treasures that won’t empty your wallet!
1. St. Vincent’s Thrift Store (Reno)
St. Vincent’s in Reno is a thrifter’s paradise tucked away in a simple building with a teal trim.
The unassuming exterior hides a wonderland of secondhand treasures inside.
This place has been a Reno institution for years, and locals know it’s the spot for serious bargain hunting.
The clothing section is massive and meticulously organized.
You can find everything from everyday basics to occasional designer gems hiding among the racks.
Their furniture area often features solid wood pieces that would cost hundreds new but can be yours for a fraction of retail.
The electronics section is worth checking out if you’re in the market for small appliances or entertainment equipment.
They test everything before putting it on the shelves, which is a huge plus.
The book corner is a quiet spot where you can dig through stacks of hardcovers and paperbacks for just a dollar or two each.
Housewares take up a significant portion of the store, with dishes, cooking tools, and decorative items galore.
Their weekly specials can make your money stretch even further if you hit the right day.
The store supports local community programs, so your shopping dollars do double duty.
Don’t overlook the jewelry counter near the front – sometimes real treasures hide among the costume pieces.
The staff is friendly and helpful without hovering over you while you browse.
Where: 500 E 4th St, Reno, NV 89512
2. Savers (Las Vegas)
Stepping into Savers on West Lake Mead Boulevard feels like entering an Aladdin’s cave of bargains.
The bright red sign welcomes you to a world of endless possibilities.
This place is enormous – we’re talking warehouse-sized huge!
Clothes hang in neat rows organized by size, type, and sometimes even color.
You could spend a whole afternoon just browsing through the shirts alone.
The furniture section might be the most exciting spot in the whole store.
You’ll find everything from sturdy dining tables to unique accent pieces that will make your home stand out.
Their book section is another hidden gem.
Paperbacks for pocket change mean you can grab a stack of summer reads without spending a fortune.
The housewares area looks like a treasure chest of domestic goodies – in the most wonderful way.
Vintage cookware, interesting lamps, and kitchen gadgets from every era are all waiting to be discovered.
With a modest budget, you could walk out with a complete outfit, home decor, and maybe even supplies for a new hobby.
Their color tag system means different discounts every week, so timing your visit right can maximize your savings.
The staff keeps everything clean and well-organized, which makes the treasure hunt much more enjoyable.
Don’t miss the seasonal section near the front – holiday decorations and seasonal items can be incredible finds.
Where: 8530 W Lake Mead Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89128
3. Opportunity Village Thrift Store (Las Vegas)
Opportunity Village Thrift Store stands out with its bright blue signage against a clean white building.
This isn’t just any thrift store – it’s a place with heart and purpose.
The store supports Opportunity Village, which helps people with disabilities in the Las Vegas area.
Inside, the space is bright, clean, and surprisingly well-organized for a thrift store.
Clothing racks stretch across a large section of the floor, with items neatly sorted by type and size.
Their furniture selection changes constantly but often includes quality pieces at a fraction of retail prices.
With a modest budget, you could easily refresh your wardrobe with several quality items and still have change left over.
The housewares section is a gold mine for kitchen gadgets, dishes, and decorative items.
Their weekly color tag sales mean different items are discounted each day, so regular visits can pay off big.
The book section is small but mighty, with paperbacks often priced at just a dollar or less.
Electronics are tested before being put on the floor, which takes the gamble out of buying used tech.
The store has a boutique section where they place higher-end items, but even these are priced reasonably.
Seasonal items get their own special display area, making it easy to find holiday decorations when you need them.
The staff is friendly and seems genuinely happy to be working there, which creates a pleasant shopping atmosphere.
Where: 324 S Decatur Blvd, Las Vegas, NV 89107
4. Buffalo Exchange (Las Vegas)
Buffalo Exchange brings a hip, boutique feel to the thrift store experience in Las Vegas.
The storefront with its distinctive logo and coral-colored entrance stands out on Main Street.
This isn’t your average thrift store – it’s curated, stylish, and surprisingly affordable.
The store specializes in trendy, current fashion rather than just any donated items.

You’ll find carefully selected clothing that feels more like a boutique than a typical thrift shop.
Their buy-sell-trade model means the inventory is constantly changing with fresh items.
The staff has an eye for fashion and displays items in a way that makes browsing feel like a treasure hunt.
With a reasonable budget, you could score a designer piece that would have cost ten times that amount new.
The men’s section is particularly impressive, which is uncommon for many secondhand shops.
They organize by style and season rather than just size, making it easier to find pieces that work together.
Vintage items get special treatment here, with dedicated sections for truly unique finds.
The accessories section is worth checking out for bags, scarves, and jewelry that can transform an outfit.
Unlike many thrift stores, Buffalo Exchange feels curated rather than cluttered.
The store’s bright lighting and clean layout make the shopping experience much more pleasant than at some other secondhand shops.
Where: 1209 S Main St, Las Vegas, NV 89104
5. Goodwill (Reno)
The Goodwill on Smithridge Drive in Reno stands out with its clean white building and signature blue logo.
This spacious store offers a little bit of everything under one roof.
The layout is open and airy, making it easy to navigate even during busy shopping times.
Clothing takes up about half the store, with clear divisions between men’s, women’s, and children’s sections.
Their color tag system means different discounts every week, helping your dollars stretch even further.
The furniture area often has solid wood pieces and gently used sofas at prices that seem almost too good to be true.
Housewares fill several aisles with everything from basic kitchen tools to quirky decorative items.
The book section is particularly impressive, with paperbacks often priced at just a dollar or two.
Electronics are tested before being put on the sales floor, which takes some of the risk out of buying used.
Their toy section is a paradise for parents looking to save on items kids might quickly outgrow.
Seasonal displays change throughout the year, making it easy to find holiday decorations when you need them.
The store is well-staffed, clean, and organized – not always a given with thrift stores.
With a modest budget, you could easily walk out with a bag full of clothing, a small piece of furniture, or a stack of books and movies.
The store supports job training programs in the community, so your shopping dollars make a difference.
Where: 5000 Smithridge Dr, Reno, NV 89502
6. Deseret Industries (Las Vegas)
Deseret Industries in Las Vegas has a clean, modern storefront that looks more like a department store than a thrift shop.
Inside, the space is bright, spacious, and surprisingly well-organized.
This store is known for its cleanliness and order – no digging through jumbled bins here!
The clothing section is massive, with items neatly arranged by size, type, and sometimes even color.
Their furniture area often features solid wood pieces and gently used sofas at prices that seem almost magical.
With a reasonable budget, you could easily furnish a small room or completely refresh your wardrobe.
The housewares section is a treasure trove of kitchen gadgets, dishes, and decorative items.
Their book area is particularly impressive, with hardcovers and paperbacks often priced at just a dollar or two.
Electronics are tested before being put on the floor, which takes some of the risk out of buying used.
The store has a boutique section where they place higher-end items, but even these are priced reasonably.
Seasonal items get their own special display area, making it easy to find holiday decorations when you need them.
The staff is friendly and the store supports job training programs, so your shopping dollars do double duty.
Don’t miss the craft supplies section if you’re into DIY projects – it’s a gold mine of affordable materials.
The store’s weekly sales can make your budget stretch even further if you time your visit right.
Where: 4655 E Flamingo Rd, Las Vegas, NV 89121
7. The Salvation Army Family Store (Carson City)
The Salvation Army Family Store in Carson City welcomes shoppers with its distinctive red shield logo.
This store might look modest from the outside, but inside it’s packed with affordable treasures.
The layout is straightforward and practical, making it easy to find what you’re looking for.
Clothing takes up a good portion of the store, with clear sections for men’s, women’s, and children’s items.
Their furniture area often has solid pieces at prices that will make you do a double-take.
With a modest budget, you could easily walk out with a small piece of furniture or a complete outfit with accessories.
The housewares section is perfect for stocking a kitchen or finding unique decorative touches.
Their book corner offers paperbacks and hardcovers at prices that let you build a library on a budget.
Electronics are tested before being sold, which takes some of the gamble out of buying used.
The toy section is a paradise for parents looking to save on items kids might quickly outgrow.
Weekly specials mean different categories are discounted on different days, so timing your visit can pay off.
The store supports Salvation Army programs in the community, so your shopping dollars make a difference.
Don’t overlook the jewelry counter near the front – sometimes real treasures hide among the costume pieces.
The staff is friendly and helpful without hovering over you while you browse.
Where: 3320 Research Way STE 100, Carson City, NV 89701
Nevada’s thrift stores are treasure troves of amazing deals and unexpected finds.
With just a modest budget, you can discover unique items, update your home, or refresh your wardrobe while supporting valuable community programs across the Silver State.
